47.text: So, we're back at Cawoods hope game lodge in South Africa

51.text: and today we're hunting a mixed bag

53.text: Guinea Fowl, Francolin and whatever comes up in front of us

58.text: So, the morning started very early, I had a knock on my door round six o'clock.

63.text: and I was welcomed by an absolutely fabulous sunrise, the sort of sunrise you only really get here in South Africa.

74.text: The morning was very cold and very frosty

78.text: In fact, it felt like a winter's day back home in England.

90.text: Now, Guinea Fowl are a strange looking creature

93.text: beautiful blue faces, a kind of mottled feathered body

97.text: a little bit like their size of a large pheasant back in the UK

100.text: and then this prehistoric looking horn that grows out of the top of their head.

107.text: So, as we were driving onto the fields this morning

109.text: the flocks took off and then they flew into the brush, into the cover

114.text: So we got out, kind of lined up around the brush

117.text: and then gently brushed out way through.

123.text: So the way we approached these birds

126.text: half it it was like a mini walked up and half of it was like a mini driven

130.text: On the walked up, we were struggling because the birds, they were just running in front

134.text: so we sort of changed tactics.

136.text: Now, we've got Bob and Alex in the bush and they were beating

139.text: and there was me, Ian and Javier and we were on the outside.

152.text: We tried to do a pincer movement on these Guineas

155.text: but it's a little bit like an army manoeuvre

158.text: they split in every different direction, they went into the thickest bush they could find

163.text: and luckily for them, that's where they are going to stay.

168.text: Guinea Fowl shooting is probably the hardest shooting you'll ever do in Africa

175.text: It's fun. I think there must of been at least 3 or 400 birds came into this block.

181.text: and I think there's maybe three, maybe four come out of it

185.text: So I think the Guinea Fowl maybe won on this one (Laughs)

191.text: But then shortly after that, I had ten or fifteen birds over me and I managed to drop one out of that

201.text: Unfortunately for me, they didn't fly my way

204.text: but Javier and Matt both got shots off and they both took birds.

220.text: On the way back, we followed the game fence that you can see that surrounds the estate

225.text: because Alex had seen three or four coveys of Orange River Francolin

229.text: Now, they are about the same size as a grouse

232.text: and they act a little bit like quail

234.text: so as you come up to them, they kind of tuck their heads down in the grass

237.text: you've got to get up, and then flush the birds and you've got to be really quick.

247.text: So here we have an Orange River Francolin

250.text: We kind of came either side of him, three of them got up in total and we managed to get one shot off

256.text: but they were a little bit too far when I took my second shot so

259.text: yeah, beautiful bird, great eating and a nice one for the bag

263.text: So I think that's so far

267.text: six Guinea Fowl and a Francolin. Not bad for a days work.

277.text: and it's this type of hunting that which I really enjoy

280.text: of course, driven shooting and waiting in hides is all very exciting

283.text: but actually getting out there, getting into the bush

286.text: tracking, finding the animals, trying to out smart the birds

290.text: is an extremely exciting form of wingshooting

293.text: and even though there aren't as many birds in here as perhaps when we go pigeon shooting

297.text: each one has been earnt, either though physical effort and endurance

301.text: or through strategically out manoeuvring the birds

304.text: or in some cases, just plain luck

308.text: and hopefully, there's more yet to come.
